"Store Management" fails to display after selecting "Paid theme" while OBW flow.

### Expected behavior

"Store Management" should be displad after selecting "Paid theme" while OBW flow.

### Actual behavior

"Store Management" fails to display after selecting "Paid theme" while OBW flow.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create any test site using JN site.
2. Install and activate WooCommerce 6.6.0.
3. Complete "Store Details" by selecting "Storefront".
4. Complete all steps on setup checklist.
5. Go to Woocommerce > Home.
6. Verify that Store Management Links are shown.
7. Click on "Store Details" on Setup Check List.
8. While finishing the OBW flow select a "Paid" theme on Theme step.
9. After the page reload, observe that "Store Management" fails to display after selecting "Paid theme".

### Video:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41110392/173368054-a70c79fe-a8e1-4f4e-b71f-db72799ae119.mp4

Language translation fails to display for "GET THE BASICS" and "GROW YOUR STORE" on "Free feature" step of OBW.

### Expected behavior

"GET THE BASICS" and "GROW YOUR STORE" should be translated to French language on "Free feature" step of OBW.

### Actual behavior

Language translation fails to display for "GET THE BASICS" and "GROW YOUR STORE" on "Free feature" step of OBW.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create any test site using JN site.
2. Install and activate WooCommerce 6.6.0-rc.3.
3. Go to Dashboard > Settings > General
4. Change the site language to a language with good translation coverage such as French (France)
5. Go to Dashboard > Updates and click on the button to update translations.
6. Go to "Free feature" step and click Dropdown Button
7. Observe that Language translation fails to display for "GET THE BASICS" and "GROW YOUR STORE" on "Free feature" step.

### Instruction Link:
https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/wiki/Release-Testing-Instructions-WooCommerce-6.6#cleanup-and-fix-translation-path-changes-33226

### Screenshot:

![#33375](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41110392/172871789-7d67fe85-4c5e-4d94-8ca4-953037dbce9c.jpg)

"WooCommerce Admin" fails to deactivate after upgrading to WooCommerce 6.6 on "Plugins > Installed Plugins" page.

### Expected behavior

"WooCommerce Admin" should deactivate after upgrading to WooCommerce 6.6 on "Plugins > Installed Plugins" page.

### Actual behavior

"WooCommerce Admin" fails to deactivate after upgrading to WooCommerce 6.6 on "Plugins > Installed Plugins" page.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create any test site using JN site.
2. Install Query Monitor
3. Install and activate  WooCommerce 6.4.1 & Skip the onboarding wizard & select "Yes count me in".
4. Install & activate WooCommerce Admin 3.2.1.
5. Go to Home > WooCommerce.
6. Observe the note "Deactivate old WooCommerce Admin version" exists.
7. Upgrade to WooCommerce 6.6.0-rc.3.
8. Observe that "WooCommerce Admin" fails to deactivate after upgrading to WooCommerce 6.6 on "Plugins > Installed Plugins" page.

### Note:- 
1. We also observed this issue while upgrading to WooCommerce 6.5.1.

### Instruction Link:
https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/wiki/Release-Testing-Instructions-WooCommerce-6.6#remove-wcadmin-deactivation-note-33028

### Screenshot:

![#33374](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41110392/172870850-b8527c8d-f5c5-4617-a56f-49347f147b37.jpg)

## User story
As a new merchant
I want to shipping options set by default
So I can review it later

## Acceptance Criteria:

Automatically set the following default shipping options:

- Free shipping in the same country as the store.
- Flat rate in all other countries.

When any of the conditions are true:
- The store sells physical products, has JP and WCS installed and connected, and is located in the US.
- The store sells physical products, and is not located in US/Canada/Australia/UK (irrelevant if JP is installed or not).
- The store sells physical products and is located in US, but JP and WCS are not installed.

ref: https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/issues/32318

   -  The store is located in the UK, Australia or Canada
 


ref: https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/issues/32318

Sometimes plugins use properties of `WP_Screen` to determine what part of the WP Admin they're in so they can, e.g. customize the UI. When the custom order tables are authoritative, we're using a custom admin page to display a list table of orders and the edit UI for single orders, since we can't use the standard screens that assume a post type. However, it seems like we are trying to make the change in UI seamless, even if the URL is different. The `WP_Screen` object for the custom admin pages betrays this though, because some key properties are different:

**Orders List Table screen**

| Prop | Posts | Orders |
|--------|--------|--------|
| `base` | `edit` | `woocommerce_page_wc-orders` |
| `id` | `edit-shop_order` | `woocommerce_page_wc-orders` |
| `post_type` | `shop_order` | _empty_ |

**Single Order screen**

| Prop | Posts | Orders |
|--------|--------|--------|
| `base` | `post` | `woocommerce_page_wc-orders` |
| `id` | `shop_order` | `woocommerce_page_wc-orders` |
| `post_type` | `shop_order` | _empty_ |

So the question is, **would it make sense to try and replicate the screen props on the respective custom admin pages?**

Here's an example of how `WP_Screen` might be used, where it seems like we should assume that the intended functionality would work regardless of which set of tables is authoritative:

```php
$current_screen = get_current_screen();
if ( 'shop_order' == $current_screen->post_type ) {
	// Do stuff.
}
```

Maybe it wouldn't make sense to modify the `base` property since it's related to the file name in `wp-admin`. But perhaps the `id` and `post_type` should be the same?

## Issue description

The use of `page.fill()` is discouraged by Playwright ([doc](https://playwright.dev/docs/api/class-page#page-fill)). Instead, `locator.fll()` should be used. This is because:

* Tests are more resilient when they use "user-facing attributes and explicit contracts such as `page.getByRole()`. We can change the implementation (DOM, classes, etc.) and as long as how the user perceives the UI (roles, labels, etc.) stays the same, our tests will still function.
* If multiple elements match the selector passes to `page.fill()`, by default the first one found will be used. This can be a source of unexpected errors and flakiness. `locator.fill()`, by default, will throw an error and fail the test if more than one element matches the criteria for the locator.

## Acceptance criteria

- [ ] Remove all use of `page.fill()` in [`plugins/woocommerce/tests/e2e-pw/tests/merchants/create-variiable-product.spec.js`](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/82a172cd066423601841cda945bbe48535552334/plugins/woocommerce/tests/e2e-pw/tests/merchant/create-variable-product.spec.js#L4) with `locator.fill()` based imlpementations
- [ ] All tests continue to reliably pass

This issue seems to dovetail with and build on the one reported by @jacoswan  in #26256

If you have a variable product with variations, and want to update the product and variations' SKU in a single CSV import, the variations are deleted, and the parent product is not updated.

The following error is shown. In this screenshot there were 4 variable products, each with 4 variations. All 16 variations are deleted and the parent products are not updated.

![qdAIL7.png](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45057772/227681852-13b261a5-b908-4532-b1df-7bf465003907.png)

If parent products and variations are imported separately, parents first with the new SKU, then the variations, the import is successful.

At the very least we ought to document this so that users can be aware that in most if not all cases they are best off separating variations to a separate import.

### Expected behavior

When products and variations already exist on the shop, they should be able to be updated in a single import, including the SKU.

### Actual behavior

If the SKU is updated in an import that contains variable products and their variations, the variations are deleted and the variable products are not updated.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Spin up a test site.
2. Create some variable products
3. Create some variations for each
4. Export these using the built-in exporter
5. Change the SKUs to a new format, including the parent column
6. Attempt to import them 
7. See error on import failure
8. Check variable products and note variations are no longer there.

undefinedRef: 
- [WordPress.org Support Forum thread](https://wordpress.org/support/topic/error-in-log-table/#post-16584189)
- [Exception added to Action Scheduler](https://github.com/woocommerce/action-scheduler/pull/806)

Acrtion Scheduler now logs an error when running a hook that does not have a hooked handler. WooCommerce creates recurring actions that are not removed when WC is deactivated. If another plugin in the install uses AS then AS will continue to attempt to run those recurring actions resulting in an error log entry:

```
2023-03-15 11:59:34 +0000 action created
2023-03-21 18:20:05 +0000action started via WP Cron
2023-03-21 18:20:05 +0000action failed via WP Cron: Scheduled action for woocommerce_cleanup_draft_orders will not be executed as no callbacks are registered.
```

We should unschedule the recurring actions on deactivation. This is safe to do as the actions will be rescheduled on activation.

In some scenarios, when you try to open the WooCommerce > Status page, the following critical PHP error appears:

```
PHP Fatal error:  Uncaught Error: Class 'WC_Plugin_Updates' not found in /srv/htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/admin/views/html-admin-page-status-report.php:31
Stack trace:
#0 /srv/htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/admin/class-wc-admin-status.php(30): include_once()
#1 /srv/htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/admin/views/html-admin-page-status.php(43): WC_Admin_Status::status_report()
#2 /srv/htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/admin/class-wc-admin-status.php(23): include_once('/Users/bernatto...')
#3 /srv/htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/admin/class-wc-admin-menus.php(305): WC_Admin_Status::output()
#4 /Users/bernattorras/Local Sites/renewbreakupbootcamp/app/public/wp-includes/class-wp-hook.php(308): WC_Admin in /srv/htdocs/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/includes/admin/views/html-admin-page-status-report.php on line 31
```

This is happening because the WC_Plugin_Updates class [is instantiated when rendering the Status page](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/includes/admin/views/html-admin-page-status-report.php#L27) without being the class included or available at this moment.

This issue was reported [here](https://github.com/a8cteam51/renew-breakup-bootcamp/issues/316). I can't always replicate this error. The minimal scenario that I've found it happening is when using WooCommerce in combination with WooCommerce Subscriptions and [CoBlocks](https://wordpress.org/plugins/coblocks/). 

Even if the issue could be coming from a conflict between other plugins, I think that it would be safe to add a conditional like this before instantiating the `WC_Plugin_Updates` class:

```
if ( ! class_exists( 'WC_Plugin_Updates' ) ) {
	include_once dirname( WC_PLUGIN_FILE ) . '/includes/admin/plugin-updates/class-wc-plugin-updates.php';
}
```

Checking the code, I see that this is a usual thing to do when using the WC_Plugin_Updates class in WooCommerce ([here](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/includes/wc-core-functions.php#L2280) for example).

### Expected behavior

The WooCommerce > Status page should be rendered without any errors.

If the `WC_Plugin_Updates` class isn't accessible for some reason (maybe a plugin conflict), it should be included to make it available again. 

### Actual behavior

For some reason, it seems that sometimes, the `WC_Plugin_Updates` class isn't available when rendering the WooCommerce > Status page, and when this happens, an error is thrown. 

### Steps to reproduce

0. I've only been able to replicate this issue when using WooCommerce + WooCommerce Subscriptions + [CoBlocks](https://wordpress.org/plugins/coblocks/). 
1. Go to WooCommerce > Status
2. Click on the Tools tab
3. Click back to the Status tab 

If you don't get the fatal error, try to repeat steps 2 and 3 a few more times.

When a new order is created the New Order email is soft bounced (sent via SendInBlue) since it contains not Quoted-Printable encoded characters.  The issue appeared right after the upgrade to 7.5.1. I have tried to replace all Greek characters from the email subject but it didn't help. During my tests i tried to resend new order notification from the orders actions and the email arrived. The difference here was that since the account i was logged had its language set to English the notification mail was  sent in English and so it was not bounced. I believe that something happens when no english characters are present in the order email. Please note that the customers receive their New Order emails without issues. Our hosting provider Siteground replied with the following when they searched on it:
"the issue is with the subject where the messages are delivered however that is a warning that there are too many special characters or letters with quotation marks on them as it is possible to be Greek characters."


### Expected behavior

The emails were created and delivered without issues to both us and the customer.

### Actual behavior

When a new order is created the email sent to our sales dept (sales@papilio.gr) doesn't arrive. Searching the SendInBlue logs we see that they were bounced because they contain Greek characters. from SendInBlue we got a response that the email has wrong encoding. If we send the New Order notification in English it is routed and delivered. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new order
2. check on inbox and we have no emails arrived
3. go to order details with admin setup in English language
4. from the order actions choose send new order notification
5. the email arrives with out issues.

Hello,

Since version 7.4.0, you changed the **quantity-input.php** template. It sets **the type of the input** to **hidden** when **product is sold individually** or **min_value = max_value**

In that template, you provide 2 actions **woocommerce_before_quantity_input_field** and **woocommerce_after_quantity_input_field**. They allows us to add more html, such as the plus/minus buttons. But, we don't know when the type of the input is hidden. This causes a problem that **our html still is showing while the input is hidden**.

I recommend that you add some parameters to your actions which let us to know when the input is hidden. Example:

```
do_action( 'woocommerce_before_quantity_input_field', $type );
do_action( 'woocommerce_after_quantity_input_field', $type );
```

Thank you!

Thus, the task could trigger "completion" track even without suggesting extensions.

2. In addition, we should consider disabling the purchase task altogether when `woocommerce_enable_setup_wizard` filter returns false or OBW is skipped. p1679373484757359/1679343077.752069-slack-C01SFMVEYAK

We have several use case of `interpolateComponents` coming from `@automattic/interpolate-components`. While there is a similar function as part of `@wordpress/element` called `createInterpolateElement` that does something very similar.

We should replace our use of `interpolateComponents` with the wp.element version, once removed we should be able to remove the `@automattic/interpolate-components` dependency as well 🎉 

Remove use cases in (there are around 54 different files across these packages/plugins that make use of it):
- [ ] `@woocommerce/components`
- [ ] `@woocommerce/product-editor`
- [ ] `@woocommerce/onboarding`
- [ ] `woocommerce/admin/client`

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] Use `createInterpolateElement` instead of `interpolateComponents`
- [ ] Removed `@automattic/interpolate-components` dependency once all items have been updated.

		return $args;
	},
	10,
	2
);
```

I have several WooCommerce stores in which I grant free shipping for orders above $65. So we have two shipping methods: - Flat rate at $5 for orders below $65 - Free shipping for orders above $65. This simple structure is not achievable by default on WooCommerce. I can set a minimum cart total to qualify for free shipping, but if a customer reaches the threshold, both the free and paid shipping options are displayed, which does not make sense and just confuses the customer, and I have to write a PHP snippet or add a plugin just to remove the paid shipping. ### Describe alternatives you've considered I've considered a few ways to fix this simple issue: 1. Add a checkbox to the **paid shipping** methods that says "qualifying for other free shipping methods removes this paid shipping method" (because sometimes stores want to set up free and paid shipping methods based on cart total, but also a fast premium shipping method that costs money regardless of the cart total). 2. Add a checkbox to the free shipping method that says "qualifying for this shipping method hides the following shipping methods:" and the possibility to select one or more shipping methods. 3. Right now, the free shipping method allows to set a minimum cart total to enable it. Why not also allowing to set a maximum cart total to display the paid shipping method? This way, I could set the minimum threshold that qualifies for free shipping, and the maximum threshold that removes paid shipping as an option. There is also a [WooCommerce developer document](https://woocommerce.com/document/hide-other-shipping-methods-when-free-shipping-is-available/) that describes possible solutions with some php snippets, however out there, there are many store managers and merchants who are not developers and this relatively easy-to-fix issue may disincentivize them to use WooCommerce in favor of other platforms. I would suggest to implement this feature in the core, as it is very easy to do and will not require extensive testing and troubleshooting. ### Additional context As you can see from the attached screenshot it doesn't really make sense to give customers a choice between the same shipping service. They will contact customer support asking what the difference is between the two options, slowing down the checkout process. ###

In WC Settings, Taxes, On the Standard Tax Rates list, it would be helpful to have the page forward/back controls at the bottom as well as at the top of screen. By the time you scroll to the bottom, if you have a lot of rates, the top has disappeared.

The same global attribute can be added to both Attributes and Options prior to saving, without any warning or error message shown to the user. The product state saved may not be what the user is expecting.

## To reproduce

With the new product editor enabled and the `product-variation-management` feature enabled.

1. Product > Add New
2. Pick a global attribute in Attributes

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2098816/214933799-87409f57-201e-4a25-87b3-77dc49c328db.png)

3. Pick the same global attribute in Options

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2098816/214933954-1d014170-ecd8-4428-9835-d66b21b3eb4b.png)

5. Go back to Attributes and note that the global attribute has been silently removed.
6. Add the global attribute back.
7. Go back to Options and note that the global attributes still are set as previously.
8. Save the product.
9. Note that the global attributes in Options are gone, and no Variations were created.
10. Note that the product is set as a variable product in the system.

###

## To reproduce

With the new product editor enabled and `product-variation-management ` feature enabled...

1. Product > Add New
2. Add some Options and have variations auto-generated
3. Save the product
4. Note that route (URL of page) is not updated from:

`/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-admin&path=%2Fadd-product`

to 

`/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-admin&path=/product/{PRODUCTID}`

This means that if the browser page is refreshed, you will not reload the product just edited. Instead, you will load the new product screen.

Replying to a product review/comment no longer automatically approves the parent review/comment. 

In the function that handles adding the reply, "handle_reply_to_review" in "woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/ProductReviews/Reviews.php", there is a check to verify the reply belongs to the correct parent (line 311 in woocommerce v 7.3.0). This check is using '===' to compare a numeric parent comment ID field to the WP_Comment objects 'comment_post_ID' property, which is a string. Using '===' to compare causes this to fail; it should use '==' instead as the core replyto comment approval function does.

### Expected behavior

Replying to a product review/comment should also approve the parent review/comment, if it is not already approved.

### Actual behavior

Replying to a review/comment adds the reply as an approved comment but does not approve the original review/comment.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to product reviews.
2. Select an unapproved comment and 'reply' to it
3. Reply is added but original comment is not set to 'approved'

If a site's default currency is set to a currency that does not use the `$` currency symbol, like the Indian Rupee (`₹`), and the site accepts payments in that currency, the processing order list at **WooCommerce > Home > Orders** will display the `$` currency symbol.

### Expected behavior

The currency symbol configured in **WooCommerce > Settings > General** and/or the currency symbol used when paying for the order will display at **WooCommerce > Home > Orders**.

### Actual behavior

The currency symbol at **WooCommerce > Home > Orders** does not respect the settings at **WooCommerce > Settings > General** or the symbol of the currency used to pay for the order.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Change the site's currency to Indian Rupee (INR, `₹`)
2. Place an order for a product.
3. Ensure the order's status is set to `Processing`.
4. Navigate to **WooCommerce > Home > Orders**
5. Note that the price listed is correct, but the currency symbol is `$` instead of `₹`.

Deleting an order with sync disabled won't count as a pending order sync, thus the order will never get deleted from the other table.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Set either table (posts or `wc_orders`) as authoritative (Settings - Advanced - Custom data stores) with sync on.
2. Create an order, verify that it exists in both the posts table and in `wc_orders`.
3. Turn sync off.
4. Trash and then delete the order.
5. Verify that the order has been deleted from the authoritative table but not from the backup table (that's expected).
6. Verify that no sync is pending (Settings - Advanced - Custom data stores) even though one order pending sync should be displayed, turning it on will change nothing.
7. Also verify that `wp wc cot sync` does nothing ("There are no orders to sync, aborting").
8. Repeat setting the other table as authoritative.

###

I'm not sure this qualifies as a bug, a concern, a software design issue, or just a non-sense from my head. Cope with me :-D When NOT using HPOS, the `woocommerce_process_shop_order_meta` action happens in `WC_Admin_Meta_Boxes::save_meta_boxes()` which runs on a POST call that is after redirected again to the order edit screen. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6853605/213860812-4479505f-ee67-45dc-a281-150d5c4d57a4.png) But when USING HPOS, the the `woocommerce_process_shop_order_meta` action happens in `...Internal\Admin\Orders\Edit::handle_order_update()` which runs a POST that is NOT redirected to the post edit screen. In fact, this happens in the middle of the HTML output, just before the order edit form is rendered. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6853605/213860878-060892b9-257a-4cef-b025-93fe7b0138d2.png) Let's say I have a custom order action, in which I will call an external API to do something (in this case create an invoice). I need to do it later in the `woocommerce_process_shop_order_meta` action so I have all the order meta data updated and ready to be used on my action, as WooCommerce does, by the way. When NOT using HPOS, i can add a admin notice with the result of the action. If all goes OK, that notice might not be important, but if there's an external API failure, I do need to properly warn the user about it. If I add a admin notice it won't show up to user in this page load, but rather when he moves away from this page to do something else. As I stated before, this might just a non-sense from me, and I might need to find another way to alert users (although that's what admin notices were designed for), but even if that's the case, I still think this is way too late to be saving an object. At this point we are WAY into HTML rendering. I'm not saying this should be done on a POST call and then redirect (like it works for CPTs), but at least wouldn't it be safer to do it around the [wp_loaded](https://codex.wordpress.org/Plugin_API/Action_Reference/wp_loaded) or [wp](https://codex.wordpress.org/Plugin_API/Action_Reference/wp) actions? ### Expected behavior Not limited to, but be able to output notices or apply redirects if needed. ### Actual behavior Order oject is updated during HTML rendering ### Steps to reproduce 1. Activate HPOS 2. Hook into woocommerce_process_shop_order_meta 3. Do your thing ###

We will need to add template data to the form and extensibility. This issue is to come up with a POC (proof of concept) for the use of templates and how the data structure should be designed for easy use and re-use.

As it stands:
- There can be multiple templates
- Templates contain sections
- Sections contain fields
- Sections can be part of multiple templates.
(Potentially some other items)

Also have a look at our current slot fills and how they are structured, we currently have everything only point up one level.
For example:
- A field defines what section it is in: `<WooProductFieldItem id="details/name" section={ DETAILS_SECTION_ID } />`
- A section only defines what tab/location it is in: `<WooProductSectionItem id={ DETAILS_SECTION_ID } location="tab/general" />`

**Acceptance criteria**

- [ ] Create a draft PR with a viable POC where the form is rendered with a defined template (taking into account some of the above info).

When:
- clicking on “Payments” tab on backend ( __/wp-admin/admin.php?page=wc-settings&tab=checkout__)
- trying to complete purchase ( __/checkout/__)
WordPress throws a fatal error.


**Temporary fix** has been found (https://wordpress.org/support/topic/woocommerce-setting-payment-tab-showing-an-error/) :
In `wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/src/Internal/Admin/WCPayPromotion/Init.php`, change the method `set_gateway_top_of_list`, within the last if statement (the short-handed one):

change this →  `$ordering [ $id ] = $is_empty ? 0 : ( min( $ordering ) - 1 )`
to this →  `$ordering [ $id ] = $is_empty ? 0 : ( min( $ordering ) )`

I have had to apply this fix at least for the last 3 WC updates I did.

I am not in a situation where I can deactivate all plugins/themes, so it's more about creating an issue to make sure others are not impacted by this rather than finding a solve for my current situation.

### Expected behavior

Displaying the payments tab / completing and order.

### Actual behavior

Fatal error

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add any product to cart
2. View basket
3. Confirm Order
4. Crash

(for backend, simple clic on "Payments" does the job)

To accommodate, we will backtrack (sorry, folks!) on the decision to block access to the `Pricing`, `Inventory`, and `Shipping` tabs. Instead, we'll allow full access to these tabs and show a banner notice with an explanation. **Design** `BaoQ3PGPnhAiJCsJtxgej3/%5BFeature%5D-fi-796%3A158534&t=S0uVUax2hFrq2FQR-4` **Acceptance criteria** - [ ] Users can access all tabs when the variations are enabled. - [ ] In each tab, we show a top-level notice reading: `This product has options, such as size or color. You should now manage each variation's price and other details individually.`. - [ ] The button reads: `Go to Options` and takes people to the `Options` tab. - [ ] The notice can be dismissed. When dismissed, it disappears from all other tabs. It cannot be brought back. We show it once per product. If someone dismissed it in the past, they'd see it again when they create a new product. ###

In the legacy experience, the users must manually generate variations after they add attributes and mark them as used for variations. If someone doesn't do that and opens such a product in the new UX, we should show an empty state with a clear CTA. It will also be handy for a situation when the user deletes all variations (only possible through Quick Actions, which are not implemented as of this moment. I've marked this AC as `Nice to have`). **Design** `BaoQ3PGPnhAiJCsJtxgej3-fi-837%3A159682&t=S0uVUax2hFrq2FQR-4` **Acceptance criteria** - [ ] We show an empty state if any attributes are marked as `Used for variations` or added as Options. - [ ] Clicking the `Create from options` button generates variations from all attribute values. - [ ] We show a loading state while the variations are being created. The height of the card remains unchanged. - [ ] [Nice to have] We show the same empty state when the user deletes (not hides/disables) all variations using the `Delete all variations` action in Quick Actions. ###

### Prerequisites

- [X] I have carried out troubleshooting steps and I believe I have found a bug.
- [ ] I have searched for similar bugs in both open and closed issues and cannot find a duplicate.

The method `WC_Customer::get_taxable_address()` has the final line:

```
return apply_filters( 'woocommerce_customer_taxable_address', array( $country, $state, $postcode, $city ) );
```

Note that it does not pass any input parameters to the filter, only the output. Specifically, `$this` is not passed, nor anything equivalent (e.g. `$this->get_id()`).

Consequently, any user of the filter cannot know which customer's taxable address is being examined. It could be any customer on the system.

To fix this, the filter should have `$this` added as a parameter, so that code hooking the filter can know *which* customer's address is being requested.

Note that consequently, any existing code in the world using this filter is likely to be assuming that the customer to be examined is the current customer (i.e. the value of `WC()->customer`) - but that this is a false assumption, since the filter will be called whenever the method is for any customer.

As an example, consider this code:

```
$customer = new WC_Customer(123); // Get customer object for user ID 123

$taxable_address = $customer->get_taxable_address();
```

Any extension code that has hooked the filter will not know that it's specifically user ID 123 that it is being asked the result for. And if it consults `WC()->customer`, it will get the wrong customer.

When trying to avoid the use of globals, we use `wc_get_product()` (like `get_post()` in WP core).

This itself will then `\WC_Product_Factory->get_product()` which will **always** construct and return a new class instance for that product.
When using `global $product` this isn't an issue, however when replacing it with `wc_get_product()` calls, it quickly gets an issue. A normal WooCommerce shop with multiple templates in a catalog loop now has 1000s of unnecessary duplicate WC_Product objects per page increasing memory usage unnecessarily.

### Expected behavior

Reuse the product from global

### Actual behavior

Creating new instance of product everytime

### Steps to reproduce

call wc_get_product()

Currently the query to get the total spent of a customer is using 2 joins on the postmeta table:

```
# woocommerce/includes/data-stores/class-wc-customer-data-store.php (line 418-426)
$spent = $wpdb->get_var(
    // phpcs:disable WordPress.DB.PreparedSQL.NotPrepared
    apply_filters(
        'woocommerce_customer_get_total_spent_query',
        "SELECT SUM(meta2.meta_value)
        FROM $wpdb->posts as posts
        LEFT JOIN {$wpdb->postmeta} AS meta ON posts.ID = meta.post_id
        LEFT JOIN {$wpdb->postmeta} AS meta2 ON posts.ID = meta2.post_id
        WHERE   meta.meta_key       = '_customer_user'
        AND     meta.meta_value     = '" . esc_sql( $customer->get_id() ) . "'
        AND     posts.post_type     = 'shop_order'
        AND     posts.post_status   IN ( 'wc-" . implode( "','wc-", $statuses ) . "' )
        AND     meta2.meta_key      = '_order_total'",
        $customer
    )
    // phpcs:enable
);
```

This will become slower overtime when postmeta table grows. Since there is already a lookup table available this query can be optimized to make use of the wc_customer_lookup and wc_order_stats table:

```
SELECT SUM(wc_order_stats.total_sales)
FROM {$wpdb->prefix}wc_order_stats as wc_order_stats
LEFT JOIN {$wpdb->prefix}wc_customer_lookup as wc_customer_lookup ON wc_order_stats.customer_id = wc_customer_lookup.customer_id
WHERE wc_order_stats.status IN ( 'wc-" . implode("','wc-", $statuses) . "' )
AND wc_customer_lookup.user_id = '" . esc_sql($customer->get_id()) . "'
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

## Workaround
There is a filter available, so in the meantime if you want better performance you can add this to your project:
```
add_filter('woocommerce_customer_get_total_spent_query', function ($query, $customer) {
    global $wpdb;
    $statuses = array_map('esc_sql', wc_get_is_paid_statuses());

    return "SELECT SUM(wc_order_stats.total_sales)
        FROM {$wpdb->prefix}wc_order_stats as wc_order_stats
        LEFT JOIN {$wpdb->prefix}wc_customer_lookup as wc_customer_lookup ON wc_order_stats.customer_id = wc_customer_lookup.customer_id
        WHERE wc_order_stats.status IN ( 'wc-" . implode("','wc-", $statuses) . "' )
        AND wc_customer_lookup.user_id = '" . esc_sql($customer->get_id()) . "'";
}, 10, 2);
```

### Additional context

## Performance comparison
On a database with nearly 6 million records in the postmeta table:
Slow query: takes 17-23 seconds
Optimized query: (instant) 0.0003s

Here is our scenario: We have a federal tax (Canada GST) and a provincial tax (BC PST) set up for our store. People in our province pay both taxes on an order shipped to our province. Occasionally the buyer is PST exempt, so if we enter an order manually in the backend, we delete the PST column from the order and save the order. So long as we don't recalculate the order again, PST will not be charged. We can then send an invoice to the buyer and they pay. No PST. No problem. 

In the old WC reporting tool, if we report taxes by code on the day that order was made, it shows the correct tax for the order. In the new analytics, if we report taxes for the day the order was made, it does not respect the decision to exempt the PST but instead recalculates the taxes based on the order info (eg shipping address), resulting in an incorrect report of the taxes we've collected! This type of error totally undermines confidence in the new analytics reporting tool. I've been trying to migrate to it but I don't have a lot of confidence in the testing that's been done on it. I hope this can be fixed soon. Thanks, John

### Expected behavior

Order tax reporting totals are correct, based on admin decisions to exempt an order from a particular tax.

### Actual behavior

see above

### Steps to reproduce

Described in the bug description.

undefinedThe product taxonomy archive header (in the product archive template: `plugins/woocommerce/templates/archive-product.php:32-46`) cannot currently be individually removed if needed/wanted.

Some themes or plugins may want to remove or replace this section and, as this chunk of the template is 'hardcoded' in place, their only option at the moment is to override the whole `archive-product.php` template. Alternatively, additional "hacky" styles might be used to hide this `<header>` element (e.g. display: none, etc), which leave unwanted HTML markup on the site simply because there's no simple option.

I think it would be useful to separate this chunk of code into its own template part & output function, and then re-hook it back into the same place, for example on `woocommerce_before_main_content` at priority 40. This would mean no current approaches to removing this section will break/need to change but the future approach could be to simply unhook it (conditionally or otherwise).

Additionally, t looks like this change might have a knock on effect with the 'Classic Template' WooCommerce Block: `https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-blocks/blob/trunk/src/BlockTypes/ClassicTemplate.php` - so a related PR will need to be created to remove this header section there as well.

When a variable product with multiple attributes has some variations that do not have all attributes defined (i.e. some attributes are left with "any" selected), variations that are marked as Out of Stock are able to be purchased **if** they are **sorted beneath** variations which are in stock. If these out of stock variations have stock management selected, and stock set to zero, upon being purchased, no stock reduction is made. ### Expected behavior You would expect that a variation which is marked as out of stock and not available for backorders, to be not available for purchase or backorders regardless of the sorting order in the variations menu. ### Actual behavior When out of stock variations are sorted below in stock variations, they become purchasable. Here's an example from a JN site I spun up for the purpose of testing. In the following screenshots, all "Rose" products are set to manage stock, with a stock of zero, and backordering disabled. All "Gold" products are set to in stock. When all attributes are selected as rose, the product shows as correctly out of stock. When any gold attribute is selected, the product is available to be purchased, regardless of the rose variations being out of stock. If out of stock variations are sorted above in stock variations, they are no longer purchasable. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Start a new WordPress install and install WooCommerce 2. the "Manage Stock" option (Inventory section) is only available if the "Enable stock management" global setting is enabled. Users may feel lost when they visit the Inventory section and cannot find an option to manage stock. Even if they know where to find the "Enable stock management", they need to get out of the product creation experience and go to WooCommerce - Settings - Products - Inventory - Enable stock management - Save changes. 

**Acceptance criteria- [ ] Show the "Manage stock?" option by default, even if the "Enable stock management" global setting is disabled 
- [ ] Enabled the "Enable stock management" global setting if the user clicks to Enable stock management at product level
- [ ] Include a tooltip informing the user about what will happen if they enable management at product level


###

there's a lot of manual work involved in adding variations. Users need to fill each field (price, description, etc) in each variation. This can be a time-consuming task when users are creating more than 1 or 2 variations.

**Acceptance criteria- [ ] Copy basic details like price and description from the parent product into each variation


###

creating the first variation is a convoluted experience, forcing the user to jump back and forth between attributes and variations, apart from having to understand the difference between the two concepts.

**Acceptance criteria- [ ] No added attributes with the "Used for variations" setting checked: show the "add attribute" form in the Variations tab along with a welcome/helper message. Ideally,  tweak the field names to make it seem like people are creating an actual variation, rather than an attribute (it'd be confusing to mix these mental models)
- [x] If there are attributes with "Used for variations" checked: automatically show them in Variations, rather than force people to add them manually (addressed on [#35807](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/pull/35807))

Added order item meta data might get lost when refunding the item. It seems the new refunded item copies the original meta data (inclusive meta ID).

Therefore, adding the same meta key on the refunded item will delete the meta key from the original item.



### Expected behavior

The meta data should be kept on the original/copied order item.

The refunded item should copy the meta data without the `meta_id` value.

### Actual behavior

The meta data is deleted from the original order item when the same meta key is added to the refunded item with uniqueness.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add meta data to new order items:
```PHP
add_action('woocommerce_new_order_item', function ($item_id, $item) {
    $item->add_meta_data('foo', 'bar', true); // or update_meta_data
    $item->save_meta_data();
}, 10, 2);
```

2. Create a new order from admin

3. Add a product

4. Set order status to `Completed` and save.

5. Notice the `foo` meta data at the order line. The meta is attached with the `order_item_id` of the line in DB.

6. Refund the item

7. The `foo` meta data is deleted from the original item and saved to the refunded item. Verify in DB.

when the user selects the variable or bundle product type, we remove the General tab where we display regular and sale price. The absence of system status communication may cause the user to feel confused about what to do next to add the price **Designs:** `zs56kcy53K7GoGhgyjcQ2R-fi-213%3A37111` **Acceptance criteria- [ ] We always show the regular and sale price fields. For product types that don't require them, like variable and grouped, we disable them, so the user cannot enter and edit values. - [ ] When the fields are disabled, we change the cursor to `not-allowed;` to indicate the fields are not interactive. They also have 50% opacity (their state should be properly reflected in the code in line with accessibility guidelines). - [ ] The fields are disabled even if they contain previously added values. - [ ] For variable products, we show a message at the top of the form. It reads. `You can manage pricing and other details individually for each product variation. Go to Variations`. The `Go to Variations` part links to the variations tab. - [ ] For grouped products, we show a message at the top of the form. It reads. `You can manage pricing and other details individually for each product added to this group. Go to Linked Products`. The `Go to Linked Products` part links to the linked products tab. - [ ] Other product types that do not use the system price field should behave similarly. 3PDs who own them should be able to show and customize a message similar to those above. - [ ] If a plugin doesn't provide a custom message, we default to `You can manage pricing and other details in one of the other tabs.` - [ ] All messages are fully translatable. **Tracks events:** - [ ] The `Go to Variations` part in the variable product type message. - [ ] The `Go to Linked Products` in the grouped product type message. ###

we don't offer any context about the difference between the long and short description fields. This can lead the user to use one of the fields with the wrong expectations, which can lead to errors and slow down the product creation process.

**Acceptance criteria:**
- [x] Improve the empty state of each field with copy explaining the differences or add a tooltip
- [x] Collapse the short description module by default
- [ ] Change the short description name to "Summary". This change can be risky as it will require updating documentation and screenshots. It should be treated as a nice to have


###

currently, it's possible to publish a product with just empty fields. Without context, users can feel overwhelmed by all the options available in the product creation experience, making it difficult to understand which fields are critical to creating a compelling product. Marking some fields as required can potentially introduce unforeseen consequences. We can start by having the title as the required field (most companies in the e-commerce space follow this approach).

**Acceptance criteria:**
- [ ] Product name field has the red asterisk on the label
- [ ]  The publish button is disabled until the user enters the name
- [ ]  On hover, we show a tooltip message: Give this product a name before saving it.
- [ ]  The publish button becomes active if the user enters at least 1 character in the product name


###

the "Uncategorized" category selected by default adds little to no value when the user is creating a new product and can create confusion.

**Acceptance criteria- [ ] If the store has at least one created category: track the most used categories and select the top one by default, or select the one that was used last.
- [ ] If the store has no categories: create an empty state with clear CTA for creating a new category

We setup our store to calculate shipping taxes based on cart items. 
The matching tax has a rate of 23% with the shipping option enable. If the shipping method choosed by the client has the tax status set as none, new orders will have the correct shipping_tax set as 0, but if we recalculate the order total using the admin panel, it will set the shipping_tax setup on our tax, ignoring the tax status setup on the shipping method.

### Expected behavior

The expected behaviour would be to check if the shipping method tax status is set as none, and the shipping tax value to remain the same.

An example from the order created from the website

"shipping_total": "3.25",
**"shipping_tax": "0.00",**
"cart_tax": "2.30",
"total": "15.55",


### Actual behavior

Example shipping_tax after recalculate order total

"shipping_total": "3.25",
**"shipping_tax": "0.75",**
"cart_tax": "2.30",
"total": "16.30"

### Steps to reproduce

1. Set base tax with a rate of 23%, and set shipping checkbox enable
2. Go to tax options set prices inserted without tax as no
3. Show prices in store with tax
4. Show prices in cart with tax
5. Set calculate tax based on client shipping address
6. Create new shipping method with tax status set as none, with a random cost
7. Create a order with the shipping method created and with a shipping address to match the tax rate created
8. Recalculate order total and see order total.

When we perform a POST request to the `/wc/v3/orders/$ORDER_ID/refunds&_method=post` endpoint, the 
 `refunded_payment` property is not part of the response, however, when we perform a GET request to `/wc/v3/orders/$ORDER_ID/refunds&_method=get`, the property can be found in the response.

Related: https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-ios/issues/6704



### Expected behavior

The `refunded_payment` property to appear in the POST request. The docs seem to include it as well on its example: https://woocommerce.github.io/woocommerce-rest-api-docs/#create-a-refund 

### Actual behavior

The `refunded_payment` property does not appear in the POST request, only in the GET request.

### Steps to reproduce

Perform POST and GET requests to the API using the refunds endpoint, and check the response details. As an example:

POST `/wc/v3/orders/$ORDER_ID/refunds&_method=post`

Response:
```
{ "data": { "id": 6680, "date_created": "2022-06-08T09:05:22", "date_created_gmt": "2022-06-08T09:05:22", "amount": "0.83", "reason": ":)", "refunded_by": 1, "meta_data": [ { "id": 3959, "key": "_wcpay_refund_id", "value": "re_3L8KoO2Ev1jcPAUs1jPqhXeL" } ], "line_items": [ { "id": 25, "name": "TEST Product!", "product_id": 6649, "variation_id": 0, "quantity": -1, "tax_class": "", "subtotal": "-0.83", "subtotal_tax": "0.00", "total": "-0.83", "total_tax": "0.00", "taxes": [], "meta_data": [ { "id": 238, "key": "_refunded_item_id", "value": "24", "display_key": "_refunded_item_id", "display_value": "24" } ], "sku": "", "price": 0.826446, "parent_name": null } ], "shipping_lines": [], "tax_lines": [], "fee_lines": [], "_links": { "self": [ { "href": "https://mywootestingstore.mystagingwebsite.com/wp-json/wc/v3/orders/6679/refunds/6680" } ], "collection": [ { "href": "https://mywootestingstore.mystagingwebsite.com/wp-json/wc/v3/orders/6679/refunds" } ], "up": [ { "href": "https://mywootestingstore.mystagingwebsite.com/wp-json/wc/v3/orders/6679" } ] } } }
```

GET: `/wc/v3/orders/$ORDER_ID/refunds&_method=get`

The leaderboard endpoints contain "rows" of stats. These are formatted like CSV data with headings and rows. The row data is output as HTML, which isn't great for native apps. It's also missing some data and the format makes it hard to add additional data without breaking anything. We should add structured data in a new field called `data`. Instead of returning data like a CSV, each object would be a set of key, value pairs like: ``` { "id": 1234, "name": "Awesome Steel Keyboard", "items sold": "3371", "net sales": "1944797.32", } ``` As a bonus, if we can omit `data` from `_fields` by default, this data will only be included if you explicitly ask for it. ### Describe alternatives you've considered We could also do this as /v4 analytics endpoints. I suspect there will be some hesitation to start introducing v4 endpoints in a piecemeal way like this though. ### Additional context A row in the product leaderboard looks like this: ``` [ { "display": "Practical Silk Gloves", "value": "Practical Silk Gloves" }, { "display": "3,345", "value": 3345 }, { "display": "$3,329,077.80", "value": 3329077.8000000077 } ], ``` In order to get the product ID, we have to parse the HTML and get the product ID from the URL. ###

###

undefinedThis is a companion to #33221. It probably should only be implemented in conjunction with that, as explained further below.

Currently data items in the analytics cache have a theoretical TTL of [one week](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/35b58245af09042934d9c726786cb3dfcb246838/plugins/woocommerce/src/Admin/API/Reports/Cache.php#L73). However, any time a relevant entity (order, product, coupon, etc.) changes or is created, the entire cache [gets invalidated](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/35b58245af09042934d9c726786cb3dfcb246838/plugins/woocommerce/src/Admin/API/Reports/Cache.php#L25), so it seems unlikely on an active store that a cache item would ever reach end-of-life. On medium/high traffic stores, this essentially means that analytics requests will never return cached data, and will always end up running expensive, slow queries.

To mitigate this, I propose that we make two changes (plus the change in #33221):

* Change the way that the cache version value ([a second-based Unix timestamp](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/35b58245af09042934d9c726786cb3dfcb246838/plugins/woocommerce/includes/class-wc-cache-helper.php#L258)) is generated to round to a particular increment, say, 10 minutes. This would mean that several entity changes clustered together, or a high rate of continuous changes, would only cause one invalidation every 10 minutes.
* Change the existing TTL from one week down to one day, or even one hour. This way, if changes happen _after_ an invalidation but still within the same 10-minute window, the data would not remain stale for very long.

The benefit of combining these changes with #33221 is that if a user notices stale data, they would be able to send an API request to immediately refresh the cache for that particular data set, rather than having to wait for the cache to expire. In the mobile apps, this would manifest as doing a "pull to refresh".

The tricky part, I think, is figuring out the best balance between cache version increment and TTL to most benefit stores, regardless of their rate of activity.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

* We could simply turn off cache invalidation altogether and rely on a low TTL. I think this would be harder to balance between high/low activity stores, with only one lever to move instead of two.

WooCommerce allows to set default image sizes via `add_theme_support( 'woocommerce' )`.

A default WooCommerce theme uses it to set the sizes for archive and singular views: https://github.com/woocommerce/storefront/blob/c012bb5edc58e900cacbe871807a566e9369758d/inc/woocommerce/class-storefront-woocommerce.php#L59-L60

WooCommerce also allows to set cropping style via _Customize > WooCommerce > Product Images_.

I use the Storefront theme.

By default, Storefront sets **416**px as a size for main image shown in single product views.

For my product, I use a featured image that is **1920** by **1222** pixels.

In the Customizer, "Thumbnail cropping" is set to "1:1".

However, main image is not properly cropped in singular view.

![Issue example](https://i.snipboard.io/dLlmWD.jpg)





### Expected behavior

I expect to have the image with size of 416x416px in single product views.

### Actual behavior

However, I am getting the image which has the proper width but not height.

![Issue example](https://i.snipboard.io/WY6poa.jpg)

**Additional info**

To further investigate this problem, I've used `wc_get_image_size()` to see what image sizes are used for `woocommerce_thumbnail` and `woocommerce_single`.

I've used the following code snippet to view sizes:

```php
var_dump(wc_get_image_size('woocommerce_thumbnail'));
	
var_dump(wc_get_image_size('woocommerce_single'));
```

As a result I've got this:

```
array (size=3)
  'width' => int 324
  'height' => int 324
  'crop' => int 1

array (size=3)
  'width' => int 416
  'height' => string '' (length=0)
  'crop' => int 0
```

So, it looks like saved settings for main image are ignored.


### Steps to reproduce

1. Make sure WooCommerce and Storefront are active.
2. Create a product with featured image that has at least 416x416px.
3. Publish product.

###

Under particular tax configurations, in combination with a coupon, the `line_items` in the `/orders/` and `/orders/{id}/` responses have excessively precision on fields such as `price`. This has led to issues refunding orders in the mobile apps based on these values, as often they are slightly higher than the order total.

These fields are more currency-like when the settings are different, or when no coupon is applied to the order. The fields that are affected are:

* line_items.taxes.total
* line_items.taxes.subtotal
* line_items.price

Note that the tax total and subtotal are always at least one place more precise than USD.

## Impact

The impact of this on Woo Mobile app users is that orders cannot be refunded in full if they include a coupon discount and these tax settings.

The refunds fail because the apps use the totals from `line_items.price` to build the amount for a refund, and in this scenario the sum will be slightly over the total for the order, which fails the refund API validation. I will also log issues in the apps to have more resilient use of this endpoint.

For full context, see p91TBi-8K2-p2.

## History
This was previously reported in https://github.com/Automattic/woocommerce-services/issues/2550, but shown to occur even when that plugin was not in use.

### Expected behavior

The REST API's response will consistently return numbers to two DP (subject to system settings) for both `price` (number) and `item_total` (string), as it does when no coupon is used.

### Actual behavior

There's a well know bug that breaks product attribute filtering because of an issue with the product attribute lookup table which is well documented here:

https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/issues/32065

A fix is still under testing here:

https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/pull/32893

While waiting for the fix to ship in the next release, the current workaround consists in disabling the product attribute lookup table by unchecking the woocommerce_attribute_lookup_enabled setting.

### Expected behavior

The unchecked checkbox for woocommerce_attribute_lookup_enabled option in Woocommerce > Settings > Products > Advanced should remain unchecked after any WooCommerce update.

### Actual behavior

WooCommerce enables the product attribute lookup table after any update.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Be sure your WooCommerce store is below version 6.5.1
2. Be sure you're using filters by attributes somewhere
3. Uncheck the woocommerce_attribute_lookup_enabled option in Woocommerce > Settings > Products > Advanced
4. Delete transient and any woocommerce cache, just in case
5. Check your filters in frontend: wow they work!
6. Update WooCommerce to 6.5.1
7. Check your filters in frontend: oh no! They're broken.
8. Go to Woocommerce > Settings > Products > Advanced and notice that the checkbox is checked again :(

undefinedAs you develop your new tables, I urge you to read up on MySQL InnoDB clustered indexes. 
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-index-types.html

 In InnoDB, the whole table's data is stored behind the primary key. There's no separate table data structure. So, you can make the tables more performant by building a composite primary key that can be used to satisfy your most common, or your worst-performing, queries.  

Primary Keys serve two purposes.

1. they uniquely identify the rows of the table. That's why many tables use the autoincrementing ID as the PK.

2. they provide rapid access to the table: WHERE filters that use the PK have immediate access to the table's data, but filters using other indexes must then look up the data using the PK.   This purpose of PKs is a solid part of RDBMS technology, but often not used. It's used by making the PK into a multicolumn index.

For example, on wp_wc_orders. You might define  the PRIMARY KEY as `(post_id, status, id)` rather than just `(id)`. That choice of columns means lookup patterns like

            SELECT * FROM wp_wc_orders WHERE post_id = ? AND status = 'pending'
            SELECT * FROM wp_wc_orders WHERE post_id = ?

would get rapid access via the PK for that query pattern. You'll have to choose the the actual PK based on your actual query patterns if you adopt this suggestion.

If your most common access filter pattern were `SELECT * FROM wp_wc_orders WHERE status = 'pending'` you'd flip the order of the columns in the PK to  `(status, post_id, id)`  

The inclusion of id as the last column in the composite guarantees the PK's uniqueness.

To make the autoincrementing id work correctly, you'll also have to put a UNIQUE KEY id (id) on the table. 



### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

I've been proving out this concept with https://wordpress.org/plugins/index-wp-mysql-for-speed/

The writeup about the keys is here.  https://www.plumislandmedia.net/index-wp-mysql-for-speed/tables_and_keys/

Issue woocommerce/woocommerce-admin#4314 referenced one particular API call whose error message gets put into a Snackbar via `createNotice()`. As of PR woocommerce/woocommerce-admin#8173 it's possible to preserve tags in messages displayed in a Snackbar if you pass `{ __unstableHTML: true }` as a third parameter to `createNotice()`. This only affects the specific Sample Products Import case, so any other API calls that display server-provided messages in a `Snackbar` might need the same change.

From @joshuatf's review:

Just noting that we still need a follow-up for this.  This solves the issue in this task, but we would need to do this in all REST API calls since this error has the potential to pop up in any of those.

I would love a more catch-all solution, but this may be the best to handle this.

### Description
When creating or editing an order, users can see a section at the bottom (a postbox component) for managing downloadable product permissions. This section stores the different downloadable product permissions that users want to add to the order. Both the "Downloadable product permissions" section and each permission (inside the section) have a toggle button, so that the components can be collapsed or expanded. If users click the toggle button of a single downloadable product permission, the whole "Downloadable product permissions" section will be toggled. I expect this section to be toggled only when we click the section's toggle button, not also the children's toggle button.

### To Reproduce
1. Create a downloadable product.
2. Attempt to create an order.
3. In the order page, go down to the "Downloadable product permissions" section.
4. Find the downloadable product you created previously and click the "Grant access" button.
5. Ensure there is a new permission for that product.
6. Click the toggle button of the permission so that the permission details are collapsed or expanded.

### Actual behavior
The whole "Downloadable product permissions" section is collapsed.

### Video
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45979455/149621658-c3a92ad0-d56c-4e12-9db1-a12347e4835b.mp4

### Expected behavior
Only the permission details are collapsed / expanded (depending on the toggle state), and the "Downloadable product permissions" section isn't collapsed or expanded, since we are not clicking the toggle button of that section.

### Desktop
* Windows 11 Pro 21H2 (64 bits)
* Google Chrome 96.0.4664.110 (64 bits)
* WordPress 5.8.2
* WooCommerce 6.0.0
* PHP 7.4.27

### Description
When editing orders, if you go to the "Downloadable product permissions" section and click the "Grant access" button without selecting any downloadable product, a "-1" is rendered in the component.

### To Reproduce
1. Create an order.
2. Open the order and go to the "Downloadable product permissions" section at the bottom.
3. Make sure you have not searched any product.
4. Click the "Grant access" button.

### Actual behavior
A text with the value `-1` appears in the component.

### Video
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45979455/149620893-0c46e051-6a58-412c-a33d-3af6972940d2.mp4

### Expected behavior
I can see 3 expected behaviours, so this would be open to discussion:
- Nothing should happen.
- Users should be notified that they need to enter a valid downloadable product so that they can grant access.
- The "Grant access" button is disable is no product is entered.

### Desktop
* Windows 11 Pro 21H2 (64 bits)
* Google Chrome 96.0.4664.110 (64 bits)
* WordPress 5.8.2
* WooCommerce 6.0.0
* PHP 7.4.27


###

### Context
When editing an order, I was able to add several download product permissions for the same downloadable product. I checked the title and download url were exactly the same in all these duplicated downloadable product permissions, and this looks superfluous to me.

I can see the point of letting users add multiple download permissions for the same product in the same order. 

Benefits:
 - If the number of downloads limit has been exceeded and merchants want to add more, they can just add another permission with another number of downloads.
 - If the download has expired, merchants can add another permission with another expiration date.

Drawbacks:
- Merchants need to have under control all the order's downloadable product permissions, because if there are multiple permissions for the same product in the same order, they might clash and cause unexpected behaviours. Keeping this situation under control when you have several downloadable products in the same order - each one with several permissions - could be messy.

There is a way of keeping these benefits and removing the drawback.

### Improvement suggestion
We could restrict merchants to add only **one** downloadable product permission for the same product in the same order. This way they just need to **update** the permission's number of downloads or the expiration date to extend the download capability and cover the benefits mentioned above. Also, this way, the drawback exposed earlier would be removed, as there wouldn't be any place for multiple downloadable product permissions for the same product in the same order.

### Priority
Things just work right now, so I'd say this could be a medium-low priority enhancement. Probably a low one if there are more urgent things to do.

### Additional context
Video of the current behaviour (explained in the Context section):
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45979455/149620167-2d25092f-f783-45d0-a3c2-76202d770d3d.mp4




###

### Context
When users skip the Setup Wizard in the first page (Store Details), they can start it later again, but it's not trivial finding out how to do so. We could think about ways to ease that step and improve the user experience.

### Improvement suggestion
When users attempt to skip the wizard, it would be interesting showing them a dialog explaining how they can start the wizard again (or providing them the link to the [documentation](https://woocommerce.com/document/woocommerce-setup-wizard/#reusing-the-setup-wizard)).

### Alternative improvement suggestion
Another approach would be showing in the dialog suggested in the improvement above how to start the wizard again by clicking the "Store Details" task in the Admin/Home page. 

Mentioning both flows in the dialog would be also a valid option.

### Priority
It's not a bug and it's a minor potential improvement of an existing feature, I'd say it's low priority.

### Additional context
In a nutshell, the process of starting again the Setup Wizard is already documented in WooCommerce's site. The improvement request is just about letting users find more easily that piece of documentation.

When the Lebanese Pound is selected as a store's currency, if the currency position is set to `left`, `left with space`, `right`, or `right with space`, the currency symbol placement is not applied consistently.

### Expected behavior

The `ل.ل` symbol should adhere to the currency position setting, and the cart total and currency symbol should be listed separately from the cart contents in the cart widget.

### Actual behavior

It always appears on the right in the shopping cart widget (even if `left` or `left with space` is selected), but it always appears on the left on the `/cart/` page, even if `right` or `right with space` is selected.

Additionally, on default themes like Storefront, the cart total and the number of items in cart are spliced together, making it difficult to read how many items are in the cart (e.g. `15.00 1 ل.ل item` instead of `15.00 ل.ل` and `1 item`.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Change the currency to Lebanese Pound.
2. Choose any currency position, and make note.
3. Enable the Storefront theme.
4. Add a product to the cart.
5. Navigate to the cart page.
6. Notice that the currency symbol positions do not match, regardless of what currency position is set in WooCommerce > Settings.
7. Notice that the cart widget at the top of the page will read `[Cart Price]` `[Number of products in the cart]` `ل.ل` `item(s)`.

For every WooCommerce REST API request using a WooCommerce API key, the key's last access time (stored in the database field `wp_woocommerce_api_keys.last_access`) gets updated 10 times.  This is obviously sub-optimal for performance.

### Expected behavior

I would expect the last access time to be updated only once (with one single SQL `UPDATE` query) per API request.

### Actual behavior

The last access time gets updated 10 times (with 10 separate SQL `UPDATE` queries) per API request.

### Steps to reproduce

1. First, I recommend using Firefox for testing this since it's going to be necessary to make REST API calls in a web browser and Firefox automatically formats JSON to make viewing much easier.  So you should start by logging in to WordPress with an Administrator account using Firefox.

2. In the WordPress admin section, click "WooCommerce", then "Settings".  Click the "Advanced" tab and then "REST API".

3. Click the "Add key" button to create a new API key.  Enter anything in the "Description" field; the "User" field should be pre-filled with your (Administrator) user account. For "Permissions", read-only access will be enough for testing purposes.  Click "Generate API key".  Copy the "Consumer key" and "Consumer secret" values and record them somewhere for future use.

4. Install the [Query Monitor](https://wordpress.org/plugins/query-monitor/) plugin.  We will use this for [analyzing REST API requests](https://querymonitor.com/blog/2021/05/debugging-wordpress-rest-api-requests/).

5. In your web browser (while you are still logged in as WordPress administrator - you need to be logged in for Query Monitor to work), visit the following URL:

```
https://example.com/path/to/wordpress/wp-json/wc/v3?consumer_key=ck_...&consumer_secret=cs_...&_envelope
```

Change `example.com`, `/path/to/wordpress`, `ck_...` and `cs_...` to match your site's URL and the API credentials you generated in step 3.  You should NOT change `https://` to `http://` because the REST API requires SSL to work.  If you only have an `http://` URL set up, as a quick hack you can edit your `wp-config.php` and add `$_SERVER['HTTPS'] = 'on';` somewhere before the "stop editing" line.  This will trick WordPress and WooCommerce into thinking that the site is being served over SSL, which is sufficient for testing the REST API.

In the JSON output you should see a `qm` key.  The duplicate SQL queries are under `qm.db_queries.dupes.queries`.  This should contain a query which looks something like:

```
UPDATE wp_woocommerce_api_keys SET last_access = '2021-12-25 04:14:03' WHERE key_id = 1
```

If your server is slow you might see some queries with one timestamp and other queries with a timestamp one second later, etc.  If your server is incredibly slow - suppose that it takes 10 seconds or more to handle the API request - then it's theoretically possible that you might not see any duplicate queries because each query could get a different timestamp.  But if your server handles the API request in a reasonable time (less than 10 seconds), you should see the duplicate queries there.

![screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1156399/147377290-e521adf7-c2c9-47e2-9690-f69249703973.png)

Currently any note is displayed to any user that has access to the **WooCommerce > Home** screen. Some of these notes focus on specific tasks like creating a product, or enabling a payment gateway and it could be that users don't have those privileges, but are still shown this note while on the WC homescreen.

We should filter notes by a users capability. This will require, either adding a `capability` column to the `wp_wc_admin_notes` table and/or adding this to our Note class, the second approach would not work for any notes coming from the remote inbox notification.

See here for more context: p90Yrv-2vK-p2#comment-6480

### Acceptance criteria
- Notes on home screen should be filtered by user capability
- A capability option should be added to the Note class
- We should be able to define the capability in our json for remote inbox notifications

This allows a user to retrieve mutable settings two way's, using our data store or making use of `wc.wcSettings.getSetting`. This could add confusion, and the latter is only for static settings.

**Just some brief context**, the following bug occurred during the project WooCommerce Store Editing Templates where we are converting WC Core PHP templates into Block Templates (https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-gutenberg-products-block/issues/4926). For V1 we essentially rendered the entire template as a single block represented as a placeholder within the editor (see screenshot below).

![Screenshot 2021-12-11 at 09 44 40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8639742/145672110-c0bc8e85-6391-466d-9bd8-f7c4facadaf0.png)

**The Bug**

During this project we found that users were unable to add variable products to their cart. The cause of this bug was because the code that [enqueues the required scripts](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/includes/wc-template-functions.php#L1710) is running _before_ the code that [registers the required scripts](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/includes/class-wc-frontend-scripts.php#L169).

This is only an issue for block templates because we are getting the block template html by running `get_the_block_template_html` which enqueues the required scripts, before we run `wp_head()`, which registers the required scripts [here](https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress/blob/master/wp-includes/template-canvas.php#L12). Resulting in a scenario where we are trying to enqueue scripts before they are registered, meaning they don't get included on the frontend.

We were able to implement a fix which meant running the `load_scripts()` method in our block template code, you can see the PR for this [here](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce-gutenberg-products-block/pull/5346). I am wondering if there is a better way to solve this problem upstream rather than patching it downstream in our template code.

### Expected behavior

Variable products get added to the users cart

### Actual behavior

Adding variable products to the cart returns an error, and they do not get added.

### Steps to reproduce

* Install WooCommerce 6.0.0 (inc beta) or greater.
* Install Woo Blocks. If the fix linked above is included in your Woo Blocks build please comment this out.
* Install and activate Gutenberg plugin and a block theme such as TT1.
* Load variable product on the frontend and try add it to the cart.
* Observe error.

**Prerequisites**

**Describe the bug**
For logged in users, the default user email address overrides session data during checkout in case the customer removes the input value and submits the form (while JS is disabled). In this case the user sees the _Billing email is mandatory_ error message but at the same time the input value is filled with the current user's email address. That is due to the override in [WC_Customer_Data_Store_Session::set_defaults()](https://github.com/woocommerce/woocommerce/blob/trunk/plugins/woocommerce/includes/data-stores/class-wc-customer-data-store-session.php#L150). Maybe some null vs. empty string checking might be necessary here which would affect the underlying `WC_Customer` implementation as well.

**Expected behavior**
The email address value should allow empty state and should not be overridden with default data during checkout/session.

**Actual behavior**
The submitted value is overridden with the current user's email address.

**Steps to reproduce the bug (We need to be able to reproduce the bug in order to fix it.)**
Steps to reproduce the bug:
1. Turn off JavaScript
2. Make sure you are a logged in as a user
3. Add any product to the cart and go to checkout
4. Remove the current value from the email input field
5. Submit the form
6. You will now notice the error message and the misleading input value filled with the default email address

### Describe the bug
A site owner reported a fatal error in the `WooSubscriptionsNotes` class.

```
An error of type E_ERROR was caused in line 204 of the file /home/customer/www/crefovi.com/public_html/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/packages/woocommerce-admin/src/Notes/WooSubscriptionsNotes.php. Error message: Uncaught Error: Call to a member function get_content_data() on bool in /home/customer/www/crefovi.com/public_html/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/packages/woocommerce-admin/src/Notes/WooSubscriptionsNotes.php:204 
Stack trace: 
#0 /home/customer/www/crefovi.com/public_html/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/packages/woocommerce-admin/src/Notes/WooSubscriptionsNotes.php(224): AutomatticWooCommerceAdminNotesWooSubscriptionsNotes->get_product_id_from_subscription_note(false) 
woocommerce/woocommerce-admin#1 /home/customer/www/crefovi.com/public_html/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/packages/woocommerce-admin/src/Notes/WooSubscriptionsNotes.php(417): AutomatticWooCommerceAdminNotesWooSubscriptionsNotes->prune_inactive_subscription_notes() 
woocommerce/woocommerce-admin#2 /home/customer/www/crefovi.com/public_html/wp-content/plugins/woocommerce/packages/woocommerce-admin/src/Notes/WooSubscriptionsNotes.php(97): AutomatticWooCommerceAdminNotesWooSubscriptionsNotes->refresh_subscription_notes() 
woocommerce/woocommerce-admin#3 /home/customer/www/crefovi.com/public_html/wp-includes/class-wp-hook.php(3
```

We can see in the stacktrace, a call is made to `get_product_id_from_subscription_note ` with a note of `false`, rather than a valid `Note` object. A possible quick fix is to check for `false` return values and defensively handle them.

A possible reason for the `false` return value is due to a race condition. The `refresh_subscription_notes` method is run on the  WordPress `admin_init` hook, but does not have a locking system to prevent multiple users on the site triggering the refresh at the same time. I think a fix for this situation would be bringing the routine into a cron or Action Scheduler job.



### To Reproduce
<!-- Describe the steps to reproduce the behavior.-->

Not yet available.

### Actual behavior:

The resulting fatal error causes WordPress to send an email to the site owner with the stacktrace.


### Expected behavior

Graceful handling and logging of the error instead of fatal error.

### Additional context
Original zendesk issue: 4553364-zd-woothemes

**Prerequisites (mark completed items with an [x]):**

**Describe the bug**

When using bulk edit on products, even on a single product, the value of a global attribute is changed if the failure mode criteria are met (described below).

**Expected behavior**

Bulk editing products should leave attributes untouched.

**Actual behavior**

Bulk editing a product that has a global attribute of "Second-hand grade" set to "MINT-" has the attribute value changed to "MINT".

**Steps to reproduce the bug (We need to be able to reproduce the bug in order to fix it.)**
Steps to reproduce the bug:
1. Create a product attribute "Second-hand grade" with terms: UNUSED, MINT, EXC++, EXC+, EXC, VG, VG-, NEW, MINT-
2. Create a product with the attribute "Second-hand grade" set to "MINT-" and publish
3. Bulk edit the product and change something, eg., add a tag

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When integrating WooCommerce into a theme which uses an existing CSS framework such as Bootstrap, it would be useful to be able to add classes from that framework to different elements rather than override the CSS manually.  This functionality already exists for the add-to-cart button on the Shop page, see solution.

A hook similar to the `woocommerce_loop_add_to_cart_args` filter, which allows the modification of classes applied to the add-to-cart button used on the main Shop page.
